div1.head: PETITION.
div1.p: To the Commissioners under the act of Congress approved the 16th of April, 1862, entitled "An act for the release of certain persons held to service or labor in the District of Columbia."

Your Petitioner, Andrew J. Harding
Exr Executor of Maryland by this his petition in writing, represents and states, that he is a person loyal to the United States, who, at the time of the passage of the said act of Congress, held a claim to service or labor against one person of African descent of the name of George Brooks for and during the life of said George Brooks and that by said act of Congress said George Brooks was discharged and freed of and from all claim of your petitioner to such service or labor; that at the time of said discharge said George Brooks was of the age of 28 years and of the personal description following: Here describe the person, so as to identify him or her; and if there be more than one slave, describe each one separately. Mulatto in color and about 6 feet high

That your petitioner acquired his claim to the aforesaid service or labor of said George Brooks in manner following: Here state how the claim was acquired, when, from whom, and for what price or consideration; and, if held under any written evidence of title, make exhibit thereof, or refer to the public record where the same may be found. The said George Brooks belonged to your petitioners father John Harding, who was a loyal citizen and resided in Montgomery County Md. His said father by & his last will and testament bequeathed said George Brooks to your petitioner and appointed him Executor. Said will is probated & recorded in Montgomery County Orphan's Court from said Court your petitioner obtained letter testimony. His father died last August.

That your petitioner's claim to the service or labor of said George Brooks was, at the time of said discharge therefrom, of the value of 1500 dollars in money. Here state such facts, if any there be, touching the value of the petitioner's claim to the service or labor of the person, as may enhance the same, and also such facts, if any, touching the moral, mental, and bodily infirmities or defects of said person, as impair the value of the petitioner's claim to such service or labor, and conclude such statement with an averment that the petitioner knows of no other infirmities or defects of said person which impair the value of petitioner's claim to such service or labor, and that he believes none other to exist. If the petitioner specify no such infirmity or defect, then his statement touching the value of his claim should conclude with an averment that he has no knowledge of any such infirmity or defect. Said Goerge Brooks is an A. No. 1 farm hand, and understands and can supervise tend and direct all the work on a farm. He is in perfect health. Trusty and reliable, and perfectly honest and could at any time have commanded the highest market price. Your petitioner knows of no mental, moral or physical infirmities to impair the value of said George Brooks

Your petitioner hereby declares that he bears true and faithful allegiance to the Government of the United States, and that he has not borne arms against the United States in the present rebellion, nor in any way given aid or comfort thereto.

And your petitioner further states and alleges, that he has not brought said George Brooks into the District of Columbia since the passage of said act of Congress; and that, at the time of the passage thereof, said Goerge Brooks was held to service or labor therein under and by virtue of your petitioner's claim to such service or labor.

Your petitioner further states and alleges, that he said claim to the service or labor of said George Brooks does not originate in or by virtue of any transfer heretofore made by any person who has in any manner aided or sustained the present rebellion against the Government of the United States.

And your petitioner prays the said Commissioners to investigate and determine the validity of his said claim to the service or labor of said George Brooks herein above set forth; and if the same be found to be valid, that they appraise and apportion the value of said claim in money, and report the same to the Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, in conformity to the provisions of said act of Congress.
div1.closer:
(Signed by) X Andrew J. Harding
Executor of John Harding
decd deceased
Witness Richd. H. Clarke

div1.head: [Form of the Oath for the Verification of the Petition.]
div1.dateline:
District of Columbia,
Washington County, ss.

div2.p: I, Andrew J. Harding being duly sworn, do depose and say, that all the several matters and things which are set forth and stated in the foregoing petition, as of my own knowledge, are true in substance and in fact; and that all the several other matters and things therein set forth and stated, as from the information of others, I believe to be true in substance and in fact.
div2.closer: (Signed by) his X mark Andrew J. Harding

div2.p: Sworn to and subscribed before me this 19 day of June A. D. 1862.
div2.closer:
(Signed by)
Wm R. Woodward
clk clerk &c
